items.title: Assad regime imprisoned hundreds of thousands in Syria | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Under now-ousted Syrian President Bashar al-Assad, tens of thousands of Syrians disappeared into the country's network of prisons. The slightest suspicion of dissent could result in incarceration. For many, it would also mean torture and death.

00:00 Assad regime imprisoned hundreds of thousands in Syria
02:09 Anwar al-Bunni, Syrian human rights lawyer AND Ibrahim al-Assil, Middle East Institute
15:15 Omar Alshogre, Human rights advocate

items.title: Man arrested over killing of healthcare executive Brian Thompson | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Police in the US state of Pennsylvania have arrested a suspect in the killing of United Healthcare CEO Brian Thompson. New York police said the man was spotted at a McDonald's near the town of Altoona. He had a firearm with a silencer and fraudulent identification matching the one used by the suspect to check into a New York hostel.

items.title: How will the security situation in Syria pan out? | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Rebel leaders in Syria have begun to assert their control, closely watched by the international community. The head of the so-called joint 'Military Operations Command,' Abu Mohammed al-Jolani has dropped the nom de guerre associated with his jihadist past and is now using his real name: Ahmed al-Shara. He's trying to bolster his legitimacy by presenting a more moderate public image. Syria's parliament says it supports the people's will to build a new future. What that will look like remains unclear, but many Syrians say it can only get better. 

00:00 What's next for Syria?
03:21 Haid Haid, Chatham House
08:42 Andrew Sinclair, Center for Global Security and Stabilization
16:14 Steven Heydemann, Smith College
21:13 Joseph Bahout, Institute for Public and International Affairs

items.title: What people outside the capital think about the Georgian pro-EU movement | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
In Georgia, pro-EU demonstrators have defied a government crackdown to gather for the twelfth straight night in the capital Tbilisi. 
Protesters burned an effigy of the pro-Russian ruling party's founder, expressing their outrage at the government's decision to halt progress toward EU accession talks. The country's pro-EU president accuses the governing Georgian Dream party of fraud, after its contested victory in last month's elections.
The protests have also spread to smaller cities, but activists outside the capital face problems in mobilizing support. 


For more news go to: http://www.dw.com/en/

items.title: How Pashtun kids struggle to get educatio | DW Stories
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Around one in three children in Pakistan is out of school, and the situation is even more challenging for children from Pashtun communities. With about 23 million people, they make up the country’s second-largest ethnic group. Pashtuns often live in remote areas that receive little government attention. As a result, literacy rates in those regions are among the lowest in the country

#dwstories #pakistan

items.title: First sitting Israeli PM facing criminal charges: How are Israelis reacting? | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is due to take the witness stand shortly, for his first appearance in his corruption trial. 
Ahead of today's proceedings, demonstrators protested outside the Tel Aviv court where the trial is taking place. Netanyahu arrived at a packed courtroom where he is facing charges of bribery, fraud and breach of trust in three cases.

items.title: Massive layoffs signal deepening crisis in German industry | DW Business
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Germany's industrial heavyweights are slashing jobs as the country struggles to escape its economic funk. Volkswagen made headlines when it said it wanted to curb employee pay and cut factories. Now, Ford and steelmaker Thyssenkrupp are saying thousands of jobs in Germany are on the line. How can Europe's top economy dig itself out of this hole?

items.title: How HTS and Turkey plan to reshape Syria | DW News Desk
items.author: DW News
items.content:
The fall of the Assad regime has changed the power equation in Syria, and the wider region. The most powerful rebel group HTS (Hayʼat Tahrir al-Sham) has declared a new chapter in Syria's history. But are the Islamists ready to rule a country ravaged by 13 years of civil war? And how will Turkey, a main rebel backer, try to gain influence in Syria after Assad's ouster?

#Syria #HTS #newsdesk

items.title: Joy and hope as Syrians in Turkey weigh decision to return home after Assad's fall | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Crowds of Syrian refugees living in Turkey have been heading to border crossings in order to return to their home country, following the fall of President Bashar al-Assad's government.

For many the prospect of returning is a hopeful one, as DW's Julia Hahn found out first hand at the Cilvegozu crossing, near the town of Antakya, southern Turkey.

Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has said his government will do everything it can to help Syrians return safely if they wish to do so.

Many of Turkey's three million strong Syrian refugee population have built deep roots in Turkey after many years spent in exile. With the security situation and the direction of Syria's new transitional government in flux, many appear to be carefully considering the decision to return.

#syria #turkey #assad 
For more news go to: http://www.dw.com/en/

items.title: What will it cost to rebuild Syria? | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
With Bashar al-Assad ousted from Syria, how much did the economy suffer in the past years? 

While Syrian government sources said, the country's economy contracted 54 percent from 2010 to 2021, economists at the World Bank estimate a drop of 84 percent from 2010 to 2023. Economists there measured light emitted at night to gauge economic activity. 

Can the rebels plug a potential €380 billion gap for reconstruction?

#syria #assad #hts
